raw_text:
India-Pakistan peace boosts trade
 
 Calmer relations between India and Pakistan are paying economic dividends, with new figures showing bilateral trade up threefold in the summer.
 
 The value of trade in April-July rose to $186.3m (£97m) from $64.4m in the same period in 2003, the Indian Government said. Nonethless, the figures represent less than 1% of India's overall exports. But business is expected to be boosted further from 2006 when the South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement starts. Both countries eased travel and other restrictions as part of the peace process aimed at ending nearly six decades of hostilities.
 
 Sugar, plastics, pharmaceutical products and tea are among the major exports from India to its neighbour, while firms in Pakistani have been selling fabrics, fruit and spices. "If the positive trend continues, two-way trade could well cross half a billion dollars this fiscal year," India's federal commerce Minister Kamal Nath said. According to official data, the value of India's overall exports in the current fiscal year is expected to reach more than $60bn, while in Pakistan's case it is set to hit more than $12bn. Meanwhile, the Indian Government said the prospects for the country's booming economy remained "very bright" despite a "temporary aberration" this year. Its mid-year economic review forecasts growth of 6-6.5% in 2004, compared with 8.2% in 2003. Higher oil prices, the level of tax collections, and an unfavourable monsoon season affecting the farm sector had hurt the economy in April-September, it said.
llama3.2:1b: India's trade with Pakistan increased by threefold in the summer to $186.3m (£97m). The Indian government expects business to be boosted further from 2006 when the South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement starts. India's overall exports are expected to reach over $60bn this fiscal year, while Pakistan's is set to hit over $12bn.
llama3.2:3b: Bilateral trade between India and Pakistan has increased threefold to $186.3m from $64.4m in 2003 as calmer relations ease travel and other restrictions. The South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement is expected to boost business further starting in 2006. India's overall exports are expected to reach over $60bn, while Pakistan's will hit over $12bn this fiscal year, with trade potentially reaching half a billion dollars by 2006.
gemma2:2b: India and Pakistan trade has increased three times since easing restrictions as part of a peace process. This growth is expected to continue with the South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement starting in 2006.  India's exports to Pakistan include sugar, plastics, pharmaceuticals, and tea. Pakistani exports to India include fabrics, fruit, and spices. The trade value between India and Pakistan is projected to reach half a billion dollars this fiscal year. Despite economic hurdles such as higher oil prices and a less favorable monsoon season, India remains optimistic about its economy's future growth.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
In the summer, India-Pakistan bilateral trade reached $186.3 million for the period from April-July to 2007, according to a recent announcement by India's Federal Government commerce minister. This marked a significant increase over the corresponding period in 2003 when the two countries had a strained relationship. Despite being less than 1% of India's overall exports, this trade boost is expected to continue from 2006 onwards, with both countries easing travel restrictions as part of the peace process aimed at ending decades-long hostilities.

Major export commodities include sugar, plastics, pharmaceuticals, and textiles for India while Pakistani firms have been selling fabrics, fruit, and spices. An estimated $15 billion is expected to flow between the two nations in 2004, with Pakistan's GDP projected to reach more than $12 billion as well. The Indian Government views this positive development as "very bright," but it remains concerned about economic forecasts that could be affected by higher oil prices and an unfavourable monsoon season affecting agriculture.

To further boost their exports, both countries eased travel restrictions and relaxed other restrictions during the summer months.
qwen2.5:1.5b: India's trade with Pakistan has tripled in a year due to improved relations, leading to expected growth in two-way trade reaching over half a billion dollars by 2006 and boosting India's overall exports to more than $60bn this fiscal year despite temporary economic challenges.
qwen2.5:3b: India-Pakistan peace boosts trade to $186.3m ($97m), up 3 times from 2003, indicating potential for further growth post-South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement. Key exports include sugar, plastics, pharmaceuticals and tea, while Pakistani firms sell fabrics, fruit and spices. Minister predicts two-way trade could reach half a billion dollars this fiscal year. Overall, India's export value expected to exceed $60bn, Pakistan's more than $12bn. Despite some economic challenges, the Indian economy is projected to grow 6-6.5% in 2004.

smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the text. It does not include any explanations or justifications for the figures, nor does it provide additional context about the trade between India and Pakistan. The focus is on presenting the main points in a clear and easy-to-understand manner.

tinyllama:1.1b: India and Pakistan's trade is growing despite political tensions, with new figures showing a threefold increase in bilateral trade during the summer period. The value of trade rose to $186.3 million (£97 million) from $64.4 million in the same period in 2003, according to figures released by India's federal commerce minister Kamal Natheya. The figure represents less than 1% of India's overall exports. Pakistan's exports to India have been sold sugar, plant-based products, pharmaceuticals, textiles, and tea. If the positive trend continues, two-way trade could reach $60 billion this fiscal year. The Indian Government forecasts growth of 6%-6.5% in 2004 compared to 8.2% in 2003, due to the impact of higher oil prices, tax collections, and a poor monsoon season affecting the farm sector.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
India and Pakistan are experiencing a significant boost in their bilateral trade due to efforts aimed at ending their decades-long hostilities, according to data from the Indian government. The value of trade increased threefold in the summer months between April and July, which is a notable improvement over the previous period when it was $64 million. This trend can be attributed to both countries easing restrictions on travel and businesses implementing new policies as part of the peace process aimed at ending the conflict.

India's export growth has been fueled by the opening up of trade relations, which include sugar, pharmaceutical products, and tea being sold in Pakistan for the first time. This has led to increased sales in these categories for both countries, resulting in higher exports of these items in both directions. If this positive trend continues, two-way trade could well cross $5 billion by the end of the fiscal year, which would mark a significant increase from current annual figures.

The growth in overall exports is expected to hit $60 billion this fiscal year, up from an estimated $52 billion last year, according to official data. This improvement is partly due to the fact that Pakistan's economy has been recovering from its recent financial crisis, and India remains a robust player in the global market, with high growth forecasts for 2004. However, these developments are not without their setbacks, as higher oil prices, poor monsoon season agricultural results, and the presence of unfavorable tax collections affected the country's economy between April and September.

In summary, both countries have seen increased trade relations that may lead to further growth in the coming years, particularly with regard to products such as sugar, pharmaceuticals, and tea. The improvement in trade indicates a promising future for both nations, especially considering their positions within the South Asian Free Trade Area (SFTA).
phi:2.7b: India and Pakistan's trade has increased significantly due to improved relations between the two countries. In the summer, bilateral trade was up threefold compared to 2003, with sugar, plastics, pharmaceutical products, tea and other exports from India and fabrics, fruits, spices and more from Pakistan. The South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement is expected to further boost trade in the future. Despite a temporary dip, the Indian economy remains strong with growth forecast at 6-6.5% for 2004, although higher oil prices, tax collections, and an unfavourable monsoon season have affected it this year.
orca-mini:3b: India-Pakistan trade is up threefold in the summer with bilateral trade valued at $186.3m (£97m) from $64.4m in the same period in 2003. Both countries eased travel and other restrictions as part of the peace process aimed at ending nearly six decades of hostilities. Indian firms are selling fabrics, fruit, and spices to Pakistan while Pakistani firms are selling sugar, pharmaceuticals, and plastics to India. The prospect for two-way trade crossing half a billion dollars this fiscal year is positive, according to India's federal commerce Minister Kamal Nath. Despite a "temporary aberration" this year, the Indian Government forecasts growth of 6-6.5% in 2004 and 8.2% in 2003, with higher oil prices, tax collections, and unfavourable monsoon weather affecting the farm sector.
hermes3:3b: India-Pak trade tripled due to calmer relations ($186.3m over Apr-Jul), with South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement expected to boost business further.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Calmer India-Pakistan relations have led to a significant increase in bilateral trade, with figures showing a 3x boost from $64.4m in 2003 to $186.3m in the summer of 2004. The South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement starting in 2006 is expected to further boost trade between the two countries. Major exports include sugar, plastics, pharmaceutical products, and tea from India, while Pakistani firms export fabrics, fruit, and spices. If the positive trend continues, two-way trade could reach half a billion dollars this fiscal year, with India's overall exports projected to be over $60bn and Pakistan's to be over $12bn. However, the mid-year economic review states that higher oil prices, tax collections, and an unfavorable monsoon season have temporarily affected both countries' economies.

Trade is expected to grow further with the South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement in 2006. India exports sugar, plastics, pharmaceuticals, and tea, while Pakistan exports fabrics, fruit, and spices. If the trend continues, bilateral trade could surpass $500 million this fiscal year. India's total exports are projected to exceed $60 billion, while Pakistan's may reach $12 billion. Despite economic challenges from high oil prices, tax collection issues, and a weak monsoon, India's economy is forecasted to grow 6-6.5% in 2004, down from 8.2% in 2003.

The value of trade is less than 1% of India's overall exports but is expected to boost further when the South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement takes effect. Both countries eased travel restrictions as part of the peace process aimed at ending nearly six decades of hostilities.
granite3.1-dense:2b: India-Pakistan relations have improved, leading to a tripling of bilateral trade during the April-July period compared to 2003, totaling $186.3m (£97m). This represents less than 1% of India's overall exports but is expected to rise significantly as both countries implement the South Asian Free Trade Area Agreement in 2006. Major exports from India to Pakistan include sugar, plastics, pharmaceuticals, and tea, while Pakistani firms sell fabrics, fruit, and spices. India's federal commerce minister anticipates that two-way trade could surpass $500m this fiscal year. India's overall exports for the current fiscal year are projected at over $60bn, and Pakistan's at more than $12bn. Despite a temporary economic slowdown due to factors like higher oil prices, tax collections, and a challenging monsoon season affecting farm sectors, India's economy is still forecasted to grow 6-6.5% in 2004, down from 8.2% in 2003.
reference: The value of trade in April-July rose to $186.3m (£97m) from $64.4m in the same period in 2003, the Indian Government said."If the positive trend continues, two-way trade could well cross half a billion dollars this fiscal year," India's federal commerce Minister Kamal Nath said.Calmer relations between India and Pakistan are paying economic dividends, with new figures showing bilateral trade up threefold in the summer.According to official data, the value of India's overall exports in the current fiscal year is expected to reach more than $60bn, while in Pakistan's case it is set to hit more than $12bn.Meanwhile, the Indian Government said the prospects for the country's booming economy remained "very bright" despite a "temporary aberration" this year.
